results.title: Pen point percussion: an introduction to hand-drawn sound of Norman McLaren
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The first part of this film presents an explanation of the principles and production of synthetic sound in motion pictures, showing Norman McLaren’s experimentation with hand-drawn sounds on film. The film is designed as an introduction to McLaren’s animated productions. An oscilloscope records what various sounds look like - the trembling strings of a guitar, the low tones of a tuba, the crow of a rooster and the human speaking voice. Norman McLaren then demonstrates on a moviola the sounds that emit from a soundtrack on which he has drawn dots, lines and triangles and we note how these sounds are synchronised with the artist’s hand-drawn animations. (6 mins.) Written by Don Peter. Photographed by Lorne C. Batchelor. Music by Louis Applebaum. (Award: Venice). The second part presents Norman McLaren’s experimental film ‘Dots’ made in 1948 which demonstrates his innovative technique and illustrates what can be created by drawing directly onto the picture and soundtrack area of film stock. (2 mins.) Other films in the collection related to this technique include ‘The Eye hears the ear sees’, ‘Synchronomy’ and ‘Loops’. (Awards: Toronto, Salerno, Rome)

results.title: Dirt cheap
results.creator_credit: David Hay, Marg Clancy and Ned Lander
results.brief_description: This film pays particular attention to uranium mining and the events and controversy surrounding the signing of the Ranger Mining Agreement - an agreement negotiated to permit a large scale, open-cut uranium mining operation at Jabiru, N.T. Whilst focusing on this event, the film explores all the issues involved in the mining of uranium in Australia.

results.title: Penalty kicks, free kicks and goal keeping
results.brief_description: Begins by dividing the action of taking a penalty kick into its five aspect. Demonstrates the strategies involved in scoring opportunities from direct free kicks near the penalty areas. Santos and Claudio shows the skills associated with goalkeeping.

results.title: Pecker
results.creator_credit: John Waters, John Fiedler, Mark Tarlov, Fine Line Features and Polar Entertainment
results.brief_description: Written and directed by John Waters (Pink Flamingos, Hairspray, Serial Mom), ‘Pecker’ is an offbeat comedy set in Baltimore, Waters’ hometown. Pecker (Edward Furlong) is a happy-go-lucky 18 year old who likes nothing better than to take candid photographs of his eccentric family and friends, as well as unusual aspects of his environment. Pecker’s family consist of: Mom (Mary Kay Place) who spends her days dispensing fashion tips to the homeless; sister Tina (Martha Plimpton) who spruiks at a local gay strip bar; grandmother, (Jean Schertler) who receives religious messages from her Holy statue of Mary; and six year old sister Chrissy who is suffering from an eating disorder. Shelly (Christina Ricci) is Pecker’s girlfriend who runs a laundromat and encourages his artistic endeavours. At an exhibition of his work, Pecker is “discovered” by Rorey (Lili Taylor), a New York art dealer who promises him fame and fortune. Pecker’s notoriety brings public ridicule to those nearest and dearest to him and threatens the integrity of his art. Also starring Mink Stole, Bess Armstrong, Brendan Sexton III, with a cameo from photographer Cindy Sherman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Waters, John Fiedler, Mark Tarlov, Fine Line Features and Polar Entertainment

results.title: Pearls in the North
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Don Murray and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Examines the pearling industry in the far north of Australia. After a post-war decline the industry now has a bright future. Nine luggers, from Broome, with Japanese and Malay crews, work the rich pearlshell beds. Shows diving techniques and a cultured pearl farm. In Italian language.

results.title: Mabo myths
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Best of Lateline”.
The High Court’s Mabo decision late in 1992 was probably the most significant legal decision ever made by an Australian Court. Sadly, it led to widespread scaremongering by sections of the community, the emergence of the ‘Mabo Myths’ and put Aboriginal spokespeople firmly on the back foot. Lateline carefully examines the myths related to the security of various types of land title in Australia and as one observor said, admirably clarifies the decision and its meaning for all Australians.

results.title: Diplomacy and deceit
results.creator_credit: Per-Eric Hawthorn, Peter Morgan and Independent Television News (GB)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Best of Lateline”.
Provides students with the inside story of how the Western powers failed to stop the conflict in the Balkans. Key political figures reveal what happened behind the scenes. It examines the continuing communist influence in what was once an Eastern Bloc country, the failure of diplomacy to end the conflict and the absence of Western military intervention.

results.title: Peege
results.creator_credit: Randal Kleiser, David Knapp, Leonard S. Berman, Bedford Productions and Phoenix Films
results.brief_description: A family visits their grandmother, who is in a nursing home, on Christmas Day. Peege, as they call their grandmother, is nearly blind and her mental and physical capacities are failing. Through a number of flashbacks the eldest grandson remembers her as she was when he was a child - full of vitality and laughter. When the others leave he talks to her of the old times, and breaks through her isolation. Cast includes Bruce Davison, Jeanette Nolan, William Shallert, Barry Livingston, David Alan Bailey, Barbara Rush.

results.title: Dirt [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Michael Covert, Trace Fraim, Kirk Hassig, Trudi Callon and Canned Pictures
results.brief_description: Two daft Texan brothers, Scooter and Junior, are left bereft and domestically helpless when their dear old Ma dies. They hatch a plan to get a woman to replace her, searching strip bars, and even approaching a prostitute to fulfil the role. When these attempts fail they kidnap DeDe (Tara Chocol), who, due to the sadistic nature of her marriage, decides to stay with them. After DeDe’s husband, a Texas Ranger, burns their house down, the brothers rob banks to support the burgeoning family. Junior, who has emotional problems, falls for DeDe whilst Scooter forms an attraction to a bank teller, Margaret, at a local branch they frequent. “Dirt” is a black comedy and farce that apes the style and energy of a Coen brothers’ film (in particular Raising Arizona) but screenwriter, director and star Michael Covert fails to achieve the same distinctly outlandish tone. Despite some slyly inspired moments, and witty one-liners, Covert ultimately opts for conventional narrative outcomes over his subversive intentions. The film trots out a slew of familiar Texan movie cliches (bigoted and corrupt police, violent husbands, dim-witted simple folk) whilst amid all the darkly themed humour, it attempts to make some salient points about the futility of male violence. Also stars Tracy Fraim, Patrick Warburton and Olivia Rosewood.
